BBFAO-BB FAO,BBIFD-BB IFAD,TF034194-EGYPT - EAST DELTA PROJECT,TF092773-EMPOWERING YOUTH COOPERATIVES
            IN RECLAIMED AGRICULTURAL LANDS IN EGYPT

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the East Delta Agriculture
            Services Project for Egypt were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately unsatisfactory. A key lesson learned from this
            project is the importance of combining social and community
            services components with infrastructural components,
            particularly in the context of land reclamation and
            Irrigation and Drainage (I&D) projects. The project
            shows that basic social infrastructure (drinking water
            supply, sanitation, electricity, health facilities, etc.)
            can be as important as the availability of I&D
            infrastructure in attracting people to newly reclaimed
            areas. The project also illustrates the important
            contribution of community development support activities.
            Although they generally account for only a small fraction of
            project overall costs, such activities are crucial elements
            for creating and developing social cohesion in a context
            where families from different regions and backgrounds have
            come together. The project clearly illustrates the critical
            importance of the project formulation and design phase, and
            their underlying assumptions. The project preparation team
            failed to recognize the risk in the Government of Egypt
            (GOE) not complying with its commitment of having all
            I&D operating properly. The team also failed to
            recognize the constraints imposed by Principal Bank for
            Development and Agricultural Credit (PBDAC) collateral
            requirements for farmers to have access to credit, which led
            to the failure of the largest component in the original
            design. On the positive side, the project showed that major
            restructuring could provide the needed corrective measures
            to compensate for weak project design.
